source.raw_text:
The Plank to Shoulder Tap is a full-body stability exercise primarily targeting the core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis), shoulders (deltoids), and arms (triceps), while also engaging glutes, quadriceps, and back muscles (erector spinae, serratus anterior) for stabilization. The movement pattern involves transitioning from a static plank, lifting one hand to tap the opposite shoulder while resisting hip rotation, emphasizing anti-rotation strength, balance, and overall body control. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary (Stabilizers & Movers): 

    • Core: Rectus Abdominis (abs), Obliques, Transverse Abdominis (deep core). 
    • Shoulders: Deltoids, Rotator Cuff muscles. 
    • Arms: Triceps, Forearms. 

• Secondary (Support & Stability): 

    • Glutes & Legs: Glutes, Quadriceps (to keep legs stable). 
    • Back: Erector Spinae (lower back), Serratus Anterior (around rib cage). [2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: Begin in a high plank (top of a push-up) with wrists under shoulders, body in a straight line, feet hip-width apart for stability. 
2. Initiation: Engage your core to prevent your hips from shifting or rocking. 
3. The Tap: Lift one hand and reach across to tap your opposite shoulder. 
4. Return & Alternate: Slowly return the hand to the floor and repeat the movement with the other arm. 
5. Key Focus: Minimize hip movement (anti-rotation) and maintain a stable, straight line from head to heels throughout the exercise. [1, 5, 8, 9]  

Benefits 

• Improves core strength, endurance, and stability. 
• Enhances balance and coordination. 
• Builds shoulder stability and upper body endurance. [2, 4, 5, 8]
